items.title: US government shutdown live: first closure since 2018 begins after funding bill fails
bullets: • The law requires agencies to furlough their ‘non-excepted’ employees
• Excepted employees stay on the job but don’t get paid until after the shutdown ends
• The Congressional Budget Office estimates that roughly 750,000 federal employees could be furloughed

items.title: First closure of US government since 2018 begins after funding bill fails – as it happened
bullets: • US government shuts down for the first time in nearly seven years
• Democratic leaders Hakeem Jeffries and Chuck Schumer blame Donald Trump and Republicans for the shutdown
• The shutdown is the first since a 35-day closure that began in December 2018 and extended into early 2019

items.title: CNBC's UK Exchange newsletter: AstraZeneca gets a shot on Wall Street
bullets: • GSK said Emma Walmsley, its CEO of nine years, will leave at the end of the year
• AstraZeneca announced plans to "harmonise its share listing structure to deliver a global listing for global investors in a global company"

items.title: What does a government shutdown mean and why is this year’s threat more serious?
bullets: • Much of the federal government officially began to shut down on Wednesday, after Congress failed to reach a funding agreement before the midnight deadline
• The shutdown will have a wide range of effects on government services and potentially the US economy
• Republicans put forward a stopgap measure to keep agencies open through 21 November, but Democrats have withheld their support

items.title: U.S. government shuts down after midnight as Congress fails to pass funding bills
bullets: • The U.S
• government shut down just after midnight on Wednesday
• Republicans and Democrats refused to budge from opposing positions on a funding deal to avoid a shutdown
• A key sticking point was Democrats' insistence on including the extension of enhanced Affordable Care Act tax credits

items.title: ‘Unprecedented in history’: global academic freedom group warns of dismantling in US
bullets: • Academic Freedom Monitoring Project counted some 40 attacks against academic freedom in the US in the first half of 2025
• Report: Attacks range from the government’s revocation of research funds to the detention and attempted deportation of foreign scholars
• Report noted that the data points to a continued erosion of academic freedom

items.title: US government shuts down after Democrats refuse to back Republican funding plan
bullets: • The shutdown is the first since a 35-day closure that began in December 2018 and extended into the new year
• It comes as Democrats look to regain their footing with voters, who re-elected Trump last year and relegated them to the minority in both chambers of Congress

items.title: Italy PM tells Gaza aid flotilla to stop or risk 'preventing peace'
bullets: • Italian PM tells Gaza aid flotilla to stop or risk 'preventing peace' Global Sumud Flotilla (GSF) says it is on "high alert" after it reaches 150 nautical miles from Gaza's shoreline
• GSF says it has entered the area where previous flotillas have been attacked or intercepted

items.title: The government shutdown fight hinges on ACA tax credits — and if immigrants should get them
bullets: • The federal government will shut down early Wednesday morning
• Republicans and Democrats are locked in a debate over enhanced Obamacare subsidies
• Republicans say Democrats want to give health care to "illegal immigrants," Democrats say that's a lie
• Democrats say they are only trying to restore coverage options that were available to immigrants having "lawful presence" in the United States before those options were eliminated

items.title: Lithium Americas stock pops 35% as government takes a stake to boost Nevada project
bullets: • Shares of Lithium Americas soar more than 35% in extended trading
• The U.S
• Energy Secretary Chris Wright says the government will take a small stake in the company
• Thacker Pass is expected to become one of the largest sources of lithium in North America
• The first phase of the project expected to begin operations in late 2027

items.title: Government shuts down after Congress fails to reach a funding agreement
bullets: • Government shuts down after Congress fails to reach a funding agreement
• Republicans and Democrats failed to agree on a pair of dueling funding bills to keep the government open
• Critical services, including Social Security, VA benefits and Medicare and Medicaid payments, will continue, but people who need resources could face delays

items.title: European leaders meet in high-security Danish summit after drone disruption
bullets: • European leaders meet in high-security European summit in Denmark
• Drones have been deployed in the country's airspace in the past week
• The EU has banned Russian drones from using its airspace in a bid to counter the threat posed by Russia
• The European Union has also banned Russian airspace from using drones

items.title: Change is brewing in the coffee industry. What lies ahead?
bullets: • Climate change is shrinking the land where coffee can grow
• The land suitable for coffee farming could shrink by 50% by 2050, a study says
• The Trump administration's tariffs threaten sales of coffee
• Experts say the coffee industry can't continue with business as usual

items.title: The world's first carbon border tax will soon go live — shaking up global trade
bullets: • The EU's Carbon Border Adjustment Mechanism (CBAM) will impose a cost on goods such as steel, fertilizers, cement, aluminum and hydrogen imported from outside the EU
• The U.S., China, India and Brazil are among the countries that have raised concerns about the policy

items.title: The AI slop drops right from the top, as Trump posts vulgar deepfake of opponents
bullets: • AI poses an obvious danger to millennia-long human fight to find the truth
• Large language model "hallucinations" and vocal deepfakes have all had a blurring effect on facts
• In such a climate, our most senior elected officials have a special duty to model truth-seeking behavior and responsible AI use

items.title: In 2022, the world axed a disease name seen as racist. US just switched back.
bullets: • The US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has reverted from using the disease name "mpox" to the obsolete "monkeypox" The name came about because scientists discovered the virus in captive Asian monkeys that had been shipped to Denmark in 1958
• The term "monkey" has a long history of being used as a slur toward Black people

items.title: Alexa’s survival hinges on you buying more expensive Amazon devices
bullets: • Amazon unveils new Alexa+ devices at its Devices event in New York City
• Amazon's Alexa+ is supposed to be more conversational and more powerful than the original voice assistant
• The new devices are supposed to have the power to make Alexa+ as successful as possible

items.title: Critics slam OpenAI’s parental controls while users rage, “Treat us like adults”
bullets: • Parents sued OpenAI over claims ChatGPT acted as a "suicide coach" for 16-year-old Adam Raine
• The lawsuit was filed by parents, Matthew and Maria Raine, alleging that "ChatGPT killed my son" OpenAI says it has been consistently rolling out safety updates since the lawsuit
• The lead attorney for the Raine family says some of the changes come "far too late"

items.title: Researchers find a carbon-rich moon-forming disk around giant exoplanet
bullets: • James Webb Space Telescope has obtained a spectrum of the ring-forming disk around a giant super-Jupiter, and found that it's rich in small carbon-based molecules
• That's despite the fact that the star it's orbiting seems to have a planet forming disk that's mostly water

items.title: President announces TrumpRx website for drugs, and pricing deal with Pfizer
bullets: • President announces TrumpRx.gov website for drugs, and pricing deal with Pfizer
• Pfizer will sell its drugs directly to consumers at discounted prices
• The website is part of a broader initiative aimed at bringing prices paid by Americans more in line with those paid in other developed countries

items.title: Former DRC president Joseph Kabila sentenced to death in absentia
bullets: • A court in the Democratic Republic of the Congo has sentenced the former president to death in absentia
• The case stems from his alleged role in backing the advance of M23 rebels in DRC’s eastern provinces
• He was also ordered to pay about $50bn in damages to the state and victims

items.title: Trump administration uses taxpayer dollars to blame Democrats for government shutdown
bullets: • A bright red banner and pop-up message first appeared Tuesday on the Department of Housing and Urban Development's website

• It was updated early Wednesday morning and warns: "The Radical Left in Congress shut down the government shut down" Staffers at multiple agencies and Cabinet departments received emails on Tuesday from the White House Office of Management and Budget

items.title: Newt Gingrich thinks Democrats 'don't have what it takes' to win shutdown
bullets: • Newt Gingrich thinks Democrats 'don't have what it takes' to win shutdown
• Newt Gingrich was speaker of the House when Republicans shut down the government twice during the Clinton administration in the mid-'90s
• Gingrich: "There's Only One Way To Win A Shutdown
• Democrats Don't Have What It Takes"

items.title: Sen. Duckworth on Hegseth's Quantico speech
bullets: • President Trump and his defense secretary addressed hundreds of senior generals and admirals at a base outside of Washington, D.C., today
• President Trump defended the use of troops in U.S
• cities while Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth told military commanders about new physical fitness and grooming requirements for uniformed personnel

items.title: Shutdown appears inevitable without last ditch intervention
bullets: • Shutdown appears inevitable without last ditch intervention, says NPR's Ailsa Chang
• The government shuts down at midnight on January 1
• The Senate is expected to vote today on two different partisan options to fund the government, at least temporarily
• Both are currently expected to fail

items.title: Bowen: Momentum is the strength of Trump's Gaza plan, but lack of detail is its weakness
bullets: • Donald Trump has made himself into a leader to whom it is hard to say no, says Bowen
• He says Hamas has 'three to four days' to decide whether to say yes or no to end the Gaza war
• Bowen: Momentum is the strength of Trump's Gaza plan, but lack of detail is its weakness

items.title: A lawsuit tries to block the Trump administration's efforts to merge personal data
bullets: • A class action federal lawsuit is filed in federal court in Washington, D.C., on behalf of the League of Women Voters, the Electronic Privacy Information Center and five unnamed U.S
• citizens
• The suit argues that the Department of Homeland Security and Department of Government Efficiency are creating "national data banks"

items.title: Trump peace plan 'ignores interests of Palestinian people', Hamas official tells BBC
bullets: • Senior Hamas official says plan 'ignores those of the Palestinian people' Hamas is unlikely to agree to hand over their weapons to the White House
• The group is also said to object to the deployment of an International Stabilisation Force (ISF) in Gaza

items.title: For Netanyahu, avoiding a peace deal may now be worse than agreeing one
bullets: • For Netanyahu, avoiding a peace deal may now be worse than agreeing one
• Netanyahu's far-right allies have threatened to leave – and possibly collapse – his government if he makes too many concessions in ending the war
• In return, he is dangling the prospect of a new, more peaceful future for the region

items.title: Pollen holds a secret that could save honeybees
bullets: • Symbiotic bacteria called Streptomyces produce antimicrobial compounds that fight deadly bee and plant pathogens
• Bees collect these bacteria along with pollen and store them in hives, creating a natural defense system
• This could lead to new, sustainable ways of protecting pollinators and crops

items.title: New rocket fuel compound packs 150% more energy
bullets: • University at Albany has created a new high-energy compound that could revolutionize rocket fuel and make space flights more efficient
• The compound releases more energy relative to its weight and volume compared to current fuels
• In a rocket, this would mean less fuel required to power the same flight duration or payload and more room for mission-critical supplies

items.title: The hidden forces inside diamonds that could make tech 1,000x faster
bullets: • Virtual charges, which exist only during brief interactions with light, play a critical role in ultrafast material responses
• Using attosecond pulses on diamonds, they showed these hidden carriers significantly influence optical behavior
• The findings could accelerate the development of petahertz-speed devices, unlocking a new era of ultrafast electronics

items.title: First living cochlea outside the body shows how hearing really works
bullets: • Scientists have kept a tiny slice of the cochlea alive outside the body, directly witnessing how hair cells amplify sound
• The finding confirms a universal principle of hearing and could pave the way for long-sought treatments for hearing loss
• The innovation is a product of five decades of work illuminating the molecular and neural mechanisms of hearing

items.title: Namibia deploys army to fight wildfire burning third of Etosha game reserve
bullets: • Namibia has begun deploying hundreds of soldiers to fight a fire that has burned through a third of Etosha national park
• The park in the north of the largely desert country is home to 114 species of mammals, notably the critically endangered black rhinoceros
• The fire had been burning since 22 September and had caused extensive ecological damage

items.title: The endangered cactus behind Mexico's sweet secret
bullets: • Barches of barrel cactus have been chopped up and seeped in vats of sugar until they're crystalized
• The Mexican government began banning the sale of acitrón in the early 2000s
• The biznaga cactus was found to be in danger of extinction due to overexploitation

items.title: Meet the woman steering Biden's bipartisan winning streak on Capitol Hill
bullets: • The White House has a long list of issues facing the nation's first two years of Congress
• President Barack Obama and his staff are working on a bipartisan agenda
• They say it's important to keep the public eye on what's happening in the U.S

items.title: Tropical Storm Imelda expected to batter parts of the southeastern U.S. this week
bullets: • Parts of the U.S
• are expected to be hit by Tropical Storm I-Bahamas
• The storm is expected to bring heavy rain to parts of the country
• Parts of South Carolina, Florida and Georgia are in the path of the storm
• The hurricane is a tropical depression

items.title: Is taking acetaminophen during pregnancy really associated with autism in children?
bullets: • President Trump suggested that taking acetaminophen during pregnancy is linked to autism in children
• Doctors disagree and say there's no strong evidence for that
• Tylenol could play a role in ongoing legal cases against the company that makes it
• NPR's pharmaceuticals correspondent, Sydney Lupkin, joins us in the comments

items.title: Meteorite collectors gather in Cincinnati this weekend for 'Meet a Meteorite'
bullets: • Meteorite collectors gather in Cincinnati this weekend for 'Meet a Meteorite' The rocks that hurtle from outer space and make it to Earth get a moment to shine
• At the Cincinnati Observatory later today, collectors will be showing off some of their treasures

items.title: How Kyrsten Sinema's decision makes Democrats' 2024 Senate map tighter
bullets: • Arizona Sen
• Kyrsten Sinema has always been a thorn in the Democrats side during her time in Congress
• She voted against her party more than almost any other member of Congress
• Now, the Democratic caucus has 48 Democrats and three independents

items.title: This tiny butterfly has the most chromosomes of any animal on Earth
bullets: • This tiny butterfly has the most chromosomes of any animal on Earth
• Unlike duplication, its chromosomes split apart, reshaping its genome in surprising ways
• Discovery sheds light on evolution, conservation, and even cancer research
• The Atlas blue butterfly is increasingly threatened by climate change and human impact

items.title: Madagascar’s president dissolves government amid youth-led protests
bullets: • President Andry Rajoelina has dissolved the government after youth-led protests over water and power cuts
• The UN says 22 people have been killed and more than 100 injured in three days of demonstrations
• Thousands of people have marched in the capital Antananarivo since demonstrations began last week

items.title: Wildfire in Namibia is contained, says PM, after criticism of response
bullets: • The fire broke out in Etosha national park, in Namibia's north, on 22 September
• The government said it suspected charcoal production next to the park was to blame
• It said 49 soldiers were being deployed to fight the fires and a further 500 on Sunday

items.title: West Africans deported from US to Ghana ‘dumped without documents in Togo’
bullets: • Eight to 10 west African nationals have been forcibly sent by Ghana to Togo, bypassing a formal border crossing, and then left on the street without passports
• Up to 28 people have arrived in the west African nation from the US so far in the deportation programme

items.title: Scared of spiders? Some former arachnophobes now are keeping jumping spiders as pets
bullets: • Thousands of jumping spiders are being flooded with requests from people who want to keep them as pets
• Social media videos of the spiders' antics have been viewed millions of times on YouTube
• Some women are trying to overcome their fear of spiders, while others are simply enchanted by their unexpected cuteness

items.title: All hail the new Fat Bear Champion
bullets: • The votes are in, and the winner of Fat Bear Week 2025 is the indomitable Bear 32, also known as Chunk
• Chunk captured voters’ hearts this year with his perseverance
• This year’s contenders got extra fat and healthy thanks to an enormous salmon run

items.title: Here’s where to preorder all of Amazon’s new Alexa devices and when they arrive
bullets: • Amazon’s latest hardware won’t begin shipping until mid-October, but you can preorder most devices starting today
• Amazon announced a redesigned Echo Dot model called the Echo Dot Max, which is more elegant than its predecessor thanks to a higher-quality 3D knit fabric and a flat face
• Amazon also announced a Kindle Scribe with a color screen

items.title: Google is blocking AI searches for Trump and dementia
bullets: • Google appears to have blocked AI search results for the query “does trump show signs of dementia” as well as other questions about his mental acuity
• Google also displayed AI overviews for queries about Biden and Alzheimer’s, stating there is “no clinical diagnosis or public proof that former President Joe Biden has dementia

items.title: TikTok, #freedom edition
bullets: • Today is the last day of The Verge’s very good subscription sale: $4 for a month and $35 for the year, for full access to the entire site
• Plus: What happens when Donald Trump faces off with Portland, a city of “angry, angry libs”

items.title: Refurbished Sonos headphones, speakers, and soundbars are up to 25 percent off right now
bullets: • Right now, Sonos is offering up to 25 percent off a range of refurbished Sonos devices
• The Sonos Era 100, Era 300, and the portable Move 2 are among the deals
• Deals include a one-year subscription of The Criterion Channel and a powerful HP gaming laptop
